Message.Title: The Sell-Off Isn't the Big Intel News
Message.Msg: It would have been impossible to convince most posters today that the sell-off wasn't the big Intel news. But, fact is, it wasn't. The big news was Intel's continuing march towards the end of the ARM era. Today there was yet more evidence that the tipping point has arrived: 1.) ARM is now a startling $13.86 off its recent 52-week high. Wow, almost fourteen bucks. Obviously due to serious recognition of the Intel threat. 2.) The Samsung event once again (just like Apple's event) demonstrated that Intel is already getting huge traction in tablets and soon will do the same with smartphones. Intel is getting the attention of the big boys and that's not a bad thing. And just as clear today is that Wall Street doesn't have the three brain cells required to realize that ARM's huge losses should be Intel's huge gains. No surprise there. They just aren't smart people...

Message.Title: Samsung touts wide appeal, new products in glitzy event
Message.Msg: [One would never know that it was a big deal or glitzy event from the comments on this board, but at least the Washington Post paid attention...] Samsung showed off several new products meant to appeal to a wide range of smartphone and tablet consumers Thursday in a glitzy preview of what’s coming from the electronics maker this year. The firm showed off an array of tablets, smartphones, cameras and laptops — as well as products that fit in multiple product categories. And while the company didn’t offer specific announcements about when consumers can expect to see most of these products on store shelves, it did offer plenty of eye candy to whet their appetites. One of the most original products the firm introduced was the convertible ATIV Q, which is a hybrid device that works as both Android tablet and a Windows PC. That means that users will be able to switch easily between Android apps and Windows 8. The ATIV Q also comes with the Samsung S Pen and full keyboard to make it more like a laptop. It weighs in at 2.84 pounds, which is a bit hefty for a tablet but lightweight for a laptop. The tablet’s 13.3-inch display is optimized for use in bright sunlight — an effort to make the device easier to tote around. The company has not announced when the ATIV Q will be available for sale. From the Washington Post

Topic.Title: Samsung touts wide appeal, new products in glitzy event

Message.Msg: Another tablet introduced Thursday, the ATIV Tab 3, is a 10.1-inch tablet that runs Windows 8 and is being marketed as the “world’s thinnest Windows 8 tablet” and also boasts the S-Pen and 10 hours of battery life. It will also come bundled with a version of Microsoft Office 2013 for free, though the firm did not specify which version that would be. Samsung also introduced two new computers: the ATIV Book 9 Lite notebook and the ATIV One 5, an all-in-one that has a narrow bezel and is less than .2 inches thick. Company executives said new, sleek forms of its tablets and computers are meant to remind users of the design of its popular Galaxy line of gadgets. Executives were quick to highlight how these products prove that the company is an innovator. “Anyone who says we are not has not been watching closely,” said Patrick Povel, head of European marketing, in what could have been a dig at the company’s ongoing patent litigation with Apple. [Gee, anyone who is not watching closely. Does he know people from this board???]

Topic.Title: Samsung touts wide appeal, new products in glitzy event

Message.Msg: All of those products and additions may seem a bit overwhelming — particularly when compared against the very streamlined product lines at Apple — but the big portfolio shows that Samsung is pursuing a strategy to be all things to all people as it fights to stay on top of the consumer tech world. “We will show you how we can bring our customers a wider variety of choice,” said D. J. Lee, Samsung’s executive vice president and head of sales & marketing. [It was quite the show according to a number of people. Apparently all of the shills on this board were too busy watching the muttonheads on Wall Street to notice...]

Topic.Title: Forbes: "Yes, the ATIV tablets were impressive..."

Message.Msg: Apple will always have their fans and so the Haswell MacBook Airs and soon to be upgraded MacBook Pro with Haswell, will sell extremely well because of the improved resolution and 80% improvement in battery life. On the Windows and Android side, Haswell is really giving computer makers lots of ammunition to get consumers to upgrade the XP and Windows 7 computers. Notebook/Ultrabooks/Hybrids with Haswell, are allowing all-day battery with unheard of graphics resolutions. The ATIV Q and ATIV Book 9 are perfect examples of this. It has only been 2 week since Haswell release and already we are selling some incredible devices...ATIV Q, Dell XPS 11, Sony VAIO Duo 13, etc. We will see even more incredible devices once the Haswell Y series ULV parts (6W SDP) and the ultra ULV parts (4.5W SDP) are released. These should allow for Core process in thin fanless tablet/hybrid designs.

Message.Title: Two dishonest derivative players!
Message.Msg: Look at the tell signs on both the NASDAQ/NYSE. What is happening is stagnation in the major indices. This happens when the large derivative players are shifting their positions. They are now moving money and are going to bet against both markets. In the past this is when large corrections take place (over 10 percent). The large derivative players are the ones that run the indices. For example look at Warren Buffet; he is a heavy derivative player that has, over the last five years, substantially decreased his position in stocks and gone the derivative route. Smart, rich player. Derivative are an easy way to hide money.......so large losses can be covered up. The SEC does not understand this and they cannot track this. The result is no regulation. It will only take one major, dishonest derivative player to send our financial systems into ruin.

Message.Title: Intel Broadwell Coming In 2014, 14 Nanometer On Track
Message.Msg: Ashraf Eassa's new article: "In my previous piece (Intel's 14 Nanometer: Setting The Record Straight), I pointed out that it was likely that it was only the LGA desktop chips that would not see 14 nanometer parts, and that they would skip right to the "tock" following "Broadwell" known as "Skylake." Well, in that article, I had common sense on my side, but in this article, I have Intel's own roadmaps - that the tech press could not be bothered to find - to prove that "Broadwell" is actually coming in the first half of 2014, proving that Intel's 14 nanometer process is not only [NOT] delayed, but Intel's "tick tock" cadence is still alive and well."

Topic.Title: Intel Broadwell Coming In 2014, 14 Nanometer On Track

Message.Msg: Thanks to Ashraf for a great job clarifying the expected arrival of the the LGA and BGA parts. Most importantly the prospect of seeing 14nm BGA parts for thin, lightweight, mobile-portable devices arrive within 12 months is absolutely amazing. Intel's competitive position is already very good, but this is stellar.

Message.Title: Intel confidend new processor will be well received
Message.Msg: Intel Confident New Processor Will Be Well Received By Nurul Hamis Izmir GEORGE TOWN, June 21 (Bernama) -- Intel Electronics (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd is confident that its recently launched Fourth Generation Intel Core processor, will be well received by the market. "Those from the government sector, especially in the field of education and even the corporates, will benefit from our latest innovation. They can use it for a variety of purposes. "The made in Malaysia processor is able to transform work with its right combination of functionality, speed and flexibility," Country Manager of Intel Malaysia and Singapore, Prakash Mallya told Bernama. About 3,000 Intel engineers worldwide participated in the making of the processor, and 30 per cent were Malaysians. Yesterday, the American multinational semi-conductor chip maker, which has been present in Penang since 1972, officially launched the new processor. It is the first to be built from the ground up for the ultrabook and the most significant change since the Intel Centrino Technology. The fourth generation Intel core processor combines the normal personal desktop performance, with a tablet-like mobility, to accelerate to a new category of two-in-one devices.

Topic.Title: Intel confidend new processor will be well received

Message.Msg: With a power level as low as six watts, the processor enables thinner, lighter, cooler, quieter and fanless designs. "The fourth generation Intel core processor offers the most significant gain in battery life enabling ever achieved by Intel, and double the graphics and significant CPU performance improvements to deliver exciting new consumer experiences," Prakash said. Intel has also expanded its range of graphics in the highly integrated system on chip (SOC) to deliver even more stunning visuals in thinner and lighter devices. This is a good news for gamers as it can double the 3-D performance. Prakash said when watching movies or surfing the internet, the new processor will bring about a 50 per cent improvement in battery life over the previous generation. Based on all these features, Intel is expecting to see a substantial portion of it in market by year-end. "We are very bullish about the adoption. It's a great product," he said, adding, Intel's partners such as Dell, Acer, Toshiba and HP, will help create consumer demand for the Fourth Generation Intel Core processor. -- BERNAMA

Message.Title: Human brain mapped in 3-D with high resolution
Message.Msg: Human brain mapped in 3-D with high resolution “BigBrain” model, the most detailed atlas yet, could improve brain scanning tools and neurosurgeons’ navigation By Meghan Rosen Web edition: June 20, 2013 Enlarge A BIG BRAIN PROJECT By slicing a brain into ultrathin sheets and digitally pasting them together, researchers have created the first 3-D high-resolution map of the human brain. Courtesy of Amunts, Zilles, Evans et al A new 3-D map of the brain is the best thing since sliced cold cuts, at least to some neuroscientists. “It’s a remarkable tour-de-force to reconstruct an entire human brain with such accuracy,” says David Van Essen, a neuroscientist at Washington University in St. Louis. Using a high-tech deli slicer and about 100,000 computer processors, researchers shaved a human brain into thousands of thin slivers and then digitally glued them together. The result is the most detailed brain atlas ever published. Dubbed BigBrain, the digital model has a resolution 50 times greater in each of the three spatial dimensions than currently available maps, researchers report in the June 21 Science. The difference is like zooming from a satellite view of a city down to the street level, says coauthor Alan Evans, a neuroimaging scientist at McGill University in Montreal. BigBrain allows researchers to navigate the landscape of the human cortex, the rugged outer layer of the brain. And unlike previous maps, the tool also lets scientists burrow beneath the surface, tunnel through the brain’s hemispheres and step slice-by-slice through high-res structural data. Around 100 years ago, neuroscientists relied on thick slabs of brain tissue to crudely chart out neural regions. More recently, imaging tools such as MRI have let researchers take a more detailed look. But even the very best MRI maps are still a little fuzzy, says Hanchuan Peng, a computational biologist at the Allen Institute for Brain Science in Seatt

Message.Title: Meet Samsung’s first Haswell ultrabook: ATIV Book 9 Plus
Message.Msg: Samsung is bringing its super-slim 13 inch ultrabook lineup into the Haswell age. The new Samsung ATIV Book 9 Plus has the same styling as the company’s earlier Series 9 ultrabooks, but under the hood it packs a shiny new Intel Core i5-4200U dual-core processor and a qHD+ high resolution display. The Samsung ATIV Book 9 Plus is also one of the first ultrabooks from the company to feature a touchscreen and a higher-than-HD display. It has an 13.3 inch, 3200 x 1800 pixel display with a capacitive touch panel. The notebook features up to 8GB of RAM, a 128GB to 256GB of solid state storage, and the notebook ships with Windows 8. From liliputing

Topic.Title: Dipping in Red already...

Message.Msg: The open interest in the SEP $27 PUT options is higher by 10,000 contracts this morning. They have a 50 cent premium and there is the August Intel dividend before expiration that is priced in. When I seen future in the money put option activity with a premium, I have to think that is PUT WRITING where they expect to get the shares back. A variation on that occurred to me this week. Someone could be writing the options as a "pre-buy" for shorting Intel. 1. it appears that someone has WRITTEN 40,000 SEP $27 PUT option contracts 2. 40,000 contracts controls 4,000,000 shares 3. TRC Capital mini offer is 4,000,000 shares at $23.75 (probably a coincidence) SHORT PUT, SHORT INTC EXAMPLE: I can WRITE 100 SEP $27 put options right now at $3.20 when INTC is $24.25. I can then immediately short 10,000 shares of Intel stock. I get the $3.20 premium for the SEP $27 for an effective INTC acquire price of $23.80. I short Intel at $24.25. The difference is $24.25 - $23.80 = $0.45 per share. There is a 22.5 cent August dividend that I would have to pay on shorted shares which would leave $0.22.5 per share profit. If I hold until Sep, my other costs are: option buying commissions borrow costs share assignment costs in Sep Any guess what the per share cost to write the 40,000 puts, borrow costs and share assignment in SEP would be for a hedge fund? Goldman Sachs?

From TechRadar: Microsoft continues to reveal details about the comprehensive update to Windows 8, now known as Windows 8.1 and formerly known as Windows Blue. Windows 8.1 will be launched at the Microsoft Build developer conference in San Francisco on June 26 and the final version will be available as a free downloadable Windows 8 update. Microsoft also said last month that there would be a preview version available before full release which we'll get on that day in late June. The "first look" blog update posted by Microsoft's Antoine Leblond in May doesn't talk about a Start button. It does, however, say that the Start "tip" will change to "be the familiar Windows logo".

Topic.Title: Tender offer

Message.Msg: Here's some more info you might find helpful. As the first person said, INTC is recommending NOT to accept. This is from INTC's website. "SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 18, 2013 – Intel Corporation recently learned of an unsolicited "mini-tender offer" made by TRC Capital Corp. to Intel stockholders to purchase up to 4 million shares of Intel common stock at $23.75 per share. TRC Capital's offer price is approximately 4.96 percent below the closing share price of Intel common stock on June 13, 2013 ($24.99), the day before the offer commenced, and the offer is for less than 1 percent of Intel's outstanding shares."

Message.Title: breakeven for 20nm ARM SoC
Message.Msg: One of the problem is that some people are way ahead of the market - so does Bohr have a point? Intel has no interest to enter the foundry fry - they just cherry pick. Glofo already dogfighting with TSMC for Rockship 28nm business - commodization will not kill Intel but it will cripple the ARM eco system - I mean companies that strictly depend on ARM design - Semico estimates that an made in 20-nm silicon that sells for $20 must ship 9.2 million units and achieve more than $180 million in revenue to breakeven. 14nm/16nm FinFet won't result in marginal die size reduction compared to 20nm !

Message.Title: Looks like High Hopes faded for these guys
Message.Msg: Stocks quoted in this article: INTC Intel Corporation (INTC) Bulls Rally at Front-Month Strike Intel Corporation (INTC) Bulls Go After Soon-To-Expire Option  Intel Corporation (INTC) Bulls Pray for Last-Minute Bounce Today's bulls bet on quick advance for INTC Intel Corporation, INTC Milissa Hudepohl Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) bulls have been snatching up last-minute calls at the June 24.50 strike, which expires at the sound of today's closing bell. In fact, roughly 18% of INTC's intraday call volume of 56,000 has crossed at the strike for a volume-weighted average price (VWAP) of $0.06. Almost all of these contracts went off at the ask price, and volume is outstripping open interest, hinting at buy-to-open activity. In order for today's call buyers to profit from their play, INTC -- currently docked at $24.25 -- has to scoot northward a mere 1.3% to finish above the breakeven price of $24.56 (strike price plus the VWAP) by the end of the today's session. As of now, prospects are unclear, considering INTC sits just 0.2% higher than it did at the opening bell. If the stock continues to linger below the 24.50 strike, today's call buyers stand to lose their initial premium paid. Technically, INTC has advanced almost 23% from the start of 2013 to its year-to-date high of $25.98, reached on June 4, before stooping to its current levels. Despite Intel's recent pullback, speculators during the last 10 sessions have bought to open more than two INTC calls for every put, according to the stock's International Securities Exchange (ISE), Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE), and NASDAQ OMX PHLX (PHLX) call/put volume ratio of 2.35. This ratio ranks in the 90th percentile of its annual range, meaning calls have been accumulated over puts at a quicker pace just 10% of the time throughout the past year.

Topic.Title: Looks like High Hopes faded for these guys

Message.Msg: "Almost all of these contracts went off at the ask price, and volume is outstripping open interest, hinting at buy-to-open activity." UNLESS the price of Intel moved up and the OMM cleared the ASK supply into his own book at the ASK price as he moved the BID up. Someone selling covered calls for a few cents profit could have offered them at the ASK. These would be SELL TO OPEN and not BUY TO OPEN. One problem with figuring out whether a buy or sell triggered the action is not tracking the underlying stock price. One trade of note even more interesting was the 18k July $25 calls. The open interest is over 100k and the date falls just after Intel earnings. There was 3.9k of Jan 2015 $30. Steady action in the far out of the money calls. These are 90 cents.

Topic.Title: Daniel Nenni

Message.Msg: Sorry Ashraf, SemiWiki is only for industry has-beens. They are simply trying to keep their names out there so that unsuspecting Asian employers will hire them long enough to make a few more bucks before a much needed retirement. They are simply shills for rent and after Intel gets done with their market they'll be working for cheap if they can find work at all. Semiwiki is for blowhards who don't want to be told that they are wrong, don't want to defend themselves as they present their skewed views of reality. They don't take comments from the general public which only proves that they are are full of #$%$. Whatever you say on on MF is open for healthy debate, both for and against your point of view. There's none of that on Semiwiki. I haven't looked at Semiwiki in well over a year. When you go to it you can see the desperation of the writers. It's just a sad state of affairs. Five years from now when ARMH has some mystical processor that will bring Intel to it's knees you can rely on Daniel Nenni to bring up the secret FAB that is 3 years ahead of Intel that will crank out this amazing processor in mountain loads sometime in the following year. But that day never comes and he kinda forgets he ever mentions it. Which reminds me, hey Nenni, how's that 20nm working out over at TSMC? Funny, I haven't heard anything about it other than you talking about the tape outs last year.
